name: sulfur stockpiling | sulfur stockpiling | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/10662/documentation

Canada is one of the bigger producers of sulfur in the world, and one of the leading exporters. About two-thirds of Canadian sulfur is recovered at natural gas operations in Alberta, with some recovered from gas in British Columbia and from oil refineries in other parts of the country.;Much of the worldwide sulfur inventories are stockpiled in Canada and Kazakhstan. This dataset concerns the stockpiling in Alberta (Canada), where the major stockpiling facilities are located.;;Sources:;-Sulfur, Joyce A. Ober, in minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/sulfur/myb1-2007-sulfu.xls

The activity starts with the piling of recovered sulfur for storage

The activity ends with the provision of the service of stockpiling the sulfur.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: dataset is valid for sulfur storage.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The sulfur is stored in a stockpile, outside.

exchanges.description:
Based on sulfur handling and storage project in Port Ridley, Alberta, Canada, 
The planned area for dry bulk sulfur storage is 5,000 m2. 
The max. capacity is 100,000 tonnes. The lifetime of the storage was not given and it has been estimated to 70 years. 

The average storage time is considered 20 years for 1 kg of sulfur. This is considered a reasonable time period, given the fact that sulfur storage are major pieces of engineering which should ensure proper storage and retrievability for decades, at least. Thus, after 20 years the stocked material should be retrieved or changed to a new placement, in order to renew the surface seal and ensure proper storage (estimation provided in written communication by Gabor Doka, 06/2012).


The  transformation is calculated as:

occupation area / lifetime of stockpile

Estimation. It is estimated a ground sealing with 50 cm gravel bed, 3 mm plastic geo-sealing sheet and 20 cm of asphalt cover.

The density of low density polyethylene is 920 kg/m3. (http://www.substech.com/dokuwiki/doku.php?id=thermoplastic_low_density_polyethylene_ldpe)

exchanges.description:
Based on sulfur handling and storage project in Port Ridley, Alberta, Canada, 
The planned area for dry bulk sulfur storage is 5,000 m2. 
The max. capacity is 100,000 tonnes. The lifetime of the storage was not given and it has been estimated to 70 years. 

The average storage time is considered 20 years for 1 kg of sulfur. This is considered a reasonable time period, given the fact that sulfur storage are major pieces of engineering which should ensure proper storage and retrievability for decades, at least. Thus, after 20 years the stocked material should be retrieved or changed to a new placement, in order to renew the surface seal and ensure proper storage (estimation provided in written communication by Gabor Doka, 06/2012).

The occupation is calculated:
20 (kg*years) *5000 (m2) *70 years /((100000000 (kg) * 70 (years) )

Estimation.
The amount of steel is estimated from a picture of a typical sulfur storage area (see link below) 

http://www.kwhconstructors.com/services.bulk.maintenance.php?gallery=pacificcoastterminalssulfurstack-rake

There are two main parts containing steel:
- 1 steel structure and conveyor. The estimated dimensions are 25m*2m*2m
- 1 steel track that has the lenght of the storage area. It is assumed a rectangular storage area with dimension of122.5m*40.8 m. The dimensions of the track are 122.5m*2m*1m

sulfur losses due to storage are negligible.
